) Purpose. This IRM Section provides information for case building, tion, storage, and delivery of workload. Guidelines and procedures and below are to ensure uniform case building, classiﬁcation, review, and of returns. (
) Audience. These procedures apply to SB/SE Field Exam employees who responsible for return identiﬁcation, selection, and delivery in Planning and Special Programs (PSP). (
) Policy Owner. Exam Case Selection (ECS) is under Headquarters tion. (

) Case building is the process of assembling available taxpayer speciﬁc research to identify possible compliance issues. Overview (

) Various studies have been conducted throughout the years to determine value of having certain information available during the pre-audit analysis tax return versus gathering the information during the audit process. These studies have concluded the resources expended gathering this information the pre-audit (classiﬁcation) phase are more than offset by the savings incurred in pursuing non-productive issues/returns. (

) This subsection deals with classiﬁcation of returns. (
) Classiﬁcation is the process of determining whether a return should be selected for audit, the initial issues to be audited, and who should conduct audit. (

) Classiﬁcation should be conducted by an experienced examiner who has received appropriate tax law training. Examiners with specialized expertise may be used to classify business returns. Classiﬁcation using online systems (such as CDE and Modernized E-ﬁle (M
)) can be done at remote via approved procedures. See IRM
, CDE Procedures. (

) National SB/SE Classiﬁcation Guidelines provide guidance to enable greater classiﬁcation consistency nationwide and to select returns for audit with that are material in scope. The classiﬁcation guidelines can be found at: mysbse.web.irs.gov/examination/tip/classiﬁcation/default.aspx. (
) Tax returns are to be selected and classiﬁed for audit by employees who will not be the examiner of the return. (
) DIF returns are scored using algorithms/models designed to score returns deliver in descending DIF score order for classiﬁcation by examiners. (
) Non-DIF returns will be classiﬁed to select returns that contain signiﬁcant issues likely to result in tax changes or that require audit to achieve compliance. (
) All returns will be identiﬁed for assignment to an RA, TCO, or a TCO Grade (TCO-
). The designation as RA, TCO, or TCO-
will be based upon the complexity of the issues involved and the degree of accounting and auditing skills required to conduct a quality audit. See IRM
, Part
- Chart of Case Grading Factors, for additional information. (
) Returns should be classiﬁed by examiners possessing experience rate with the type of return and activity code they are classifying. (

) Individual returns selected for audit for revenue agents should contain issues requiring accounting skills of a revenue agent. Individual returns selected for audit not requiring the accounting skills of a revenue agent may be selected audit for revenue agents if tax compliance officers (TCOs) (including TCOs) are not available in the geographic location of the taxpayer or if the returns are needed for training.

) The primary objective in selecting returns for audit is to promote the highest degree of voluntary compliance on the part of taxpayers while making the efficient use of ﬁnite examination staffing and other resources. Employees must exercise their professional judgment, not personal opinions, when return selection decisions. The subsections below discuss the instructions performing return classiﬁcation. (
) Each Area should prepare Area speciﬁc classiﬁcation instructions covering following topics: a. Local issues b. Questionable practitioners (

Building, Classiﬁcation, Storage and Delivery 4.1.5

) Determination of RA or TCO exam — One of the key contributions to the success or failure of our exam program is the selection of the proper to conduct the exam. If we are to meet the exam plan, it is essential we returns most adaptable for office interviews to TCOs and those requiring the skills of a revenue agent to RAs. This decision is very important because the planned time of an audit of a business return for TCOs is substantially less than the planned time for RAs. However, substantial issues should not be excluded to convert what would be a RA assignment, to a TCO assignment. The issues discussed below are meant only as a guide. In addition to ering these items, heavy reliance must be placed on judgment and Once determined the return will be selected for audit, it must be decided if audit should be conducted by a RA, a TCO, or a TCO-
In making this mination, the classiﬁer must give consideration to the type(s) of issue(s) identiﬁed for exam. (

) Below are examples of classiﬁed items which generally cause the return to identiﬁed for a RA: a. Issues which require on-site inspection of the taxpayer’s books, or assets. b. Gains or losses on Schedule D from ﬂow through entities. c. Returns with unusually complex Schedule E activities. d. Donations of real property which would involve an engineering e. Voluminous records. f. Complex accounting method. g. Extensive time frame required to complete the audit. h. Inventories are substantial and material. i. Termination of business before the end of the taxable year. j. ) The general instructions for individual and corporate returns apply equally partnership returns. The returns must be scrutinized both as to line items the return as a whole in selecting returns with the highest audit potential. Issues to consider include but are not limited to: (

) Initial or ﬁrst year returns are often productive. Common issues are: a. Contributions to capital for possible recognition of gain or loss at the partners’ levels. b. Partners with no contributed capital where services may have been performed in exchange for the partnership interest. c. Large loss claimed on returns commencing business late in the year. d. Large loss claimed in relation to investment. e. Loss claimed in excess of investment through non-recourse Loan and prepaid interest costs should be amortized over the life of loan. f. Large depreciation deduction where property may not have been in service during the year. g. Start-up expenses (management fees, license fees, etc.) which capitalized. (
) Final year returns are often productive. Common issues are: a. Negative capital account considerations. b. Resolution of liabilities. c. Proper consideration of distribution of assets. (

) Other areas applicable to partnerships: a. Additional contributions by a partner which could constitute a sale or exchange. b. Special allocation of losses or speciﬁc deductions to partners. c. Determine if there has been a change of ownership and consider allocations of distributive share items and potential basis d. Withdrawal by partners may include “phantom gain” through of liabilities by others. e. The sale or exchange of partnership assets may result in recapture ordinary income. f. Component or other depreciation method resulting in shorter than guideline lives. g. Disguised sales or mixing bowl transactions triggered by improper contribution and distribution beneﬁts. (
) Be cognizant of potential employment tax issues when classifying income returns. Caution: Worker classiﬁcation determinations can create safe harbor under

) The PSP territory manager is responsible for monitoring return inventories. Lean inventories should be maintained to limit costly excess surveys and to allow for changing workload priorities. However, a high percentage of inventory may be warranted at speciﬁc times: for example, a. Providing returns for training. b. Major computer programming changes that may delay the ﬁlling of orders. For example, implementation of major changes to Audit tion Management System (AIMS), Examination Records Control (ERCS), etc. (

for over two to four months could indicate use of the return order and delivery system. If the Compliance Data Environ- ment (CDE) system is being used, two months of inventory should be sufficient. If the Martinsburg Computing Center (MCC) system is used, four months of inventory should be sufficient. (
) The inventory of selected returns may be stored in the area office or the campus. (

) Although the inventory of selected returns may be stored in the area office or the campus, storage at the campus for paper returns produces certain cost savings and operating efficiencies. These include the following: a. More control over and information about inventories. b. Reduction of simultaneous audits. c. Assurance that priority returns and returns with the highest DIF scores are scheduled ﬁrst. d. Clerical efficiencies. e. Reduction in shipping costs. f. Reduction in storage costs. g. Uniformity among the examination areas. h. Weekly information from AIMS. For example, address changes are matically made when the Centralized Files and Scheduling (CF&S) database is matched weekly against the AIMS database.
